pr_title: SONARJAVA-3260 RSPEC-2612 Setting loose file permissions is security-sensitive

timeline.message: SONARJAVA-3260 RSPEC-2612 Setting loose file permissions is security-sensitive
SONARJAVA-3260 RSPEC-2612 Setting loose file permissions is security-sensitive

timeline.body:
We should support the sticky bit, setguid, setuid. Those bits are set using ocal 4 digits:
```
runtime.exec("chmod 1770 file.json"); // FP
runtime.exec("chmod 3770 file.json"); // FP
runtime.exec("chmod 0770 file.json"); // FP
```
We should only consider an isolated octal number:
```
runtime.exec("chmod 770 file111.json"); // FP
```
This a proposal:
```
"(^|\\s)[0-7]{2,3}[1-7](\\s|$)"
```

timeline.body:
The `exec` method accepts a string array in order to separate the command from the arguments, the correct form should be:
```
runtime.exec(new String[] {"chmod", "777", "file.json"});
```
I think that putting a hardcoded filename is a corner case. In real-life examples, I don't expect to see the above example or this one:
```
runtime.exec("chmod 777 file.json");
```
Usually the file name is a variable, and developers probablly use this form:
```
runtime.exec(new String[] {"chmod", "777", filename});
runtime.exec(new String[] {"/bin/chmod", "--recursive", "777", filename});
```
Like in those CVEs: [Recent Java exploitation trends and malware](https://media.blackhat.com/bh-us-12/Briefings/Oh/BH_US_12_Oh_Recent_Java_Exploitation_Trends_and_Malware_WP.pdf)

And if we want to support `exec` with a string argument, It should probably be this form:
```
runtime.exec("chmod 777 \"" + filename + "\"");
```

timeline.body:
`o` means `others` and `a` means `all` (including `others`), this is a false-negative:
```
chmod a+rwx file.json
```
`o` is not always after `u` `g` `a`, this is a false-negative:
```
chmod ou+r file.json
```
And unfortunalty, `u` `g` `o` `a` are optional, and the default value is `all`, this is a false-negative:
```
chmod +rwx file.json
```
This a proposal:
```
"(^|\\s|,)([ug]*+[ao][ugao]*+)?[+=][sStT]*+[rwxX][rwxXsStT]*+(\\s|,|$)"
```
And some noncompliant examples:
```
    runtime.exec("chmod +w file.json"); // Noncompliant
    runtime.exec("chmod a+w file.json"); // Noncompliant
    runtime.exec("chmod =rwx file.json"); // Noncompliant
    runtime.exec("chmod u=rwx,g=rx,o=r file.json"); // Noncompliant
```

timeline.body:
`--recursive` is just one of the possible options that can be pass to `chmod`, but there are others and multiple options can be passed.
No need to know at which index is the `mode` argument, we can safely test `isSensisitiveChmodMode` on all the `initializers` list (skipping first).
